channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: The Bolsonaro trial is underway — and Trump says he's watching
item.description: Brazil's highest court has begun the trial of former President Jair Bolsonaro for allegedly attempting a coup. President Trump says he is watching the trial and has demanded it be dropped.

item.title: How free-ranging bison are reshaping Yellowstone's grasslands
item.description: A new study finds free roaming bison in Yellowstone National Park are reshaping the ecosystem. They have had a positive effect on grasses and soil, but some changes may not be for the better.

item.title: More Colombia, less Brazil? How tariffs could change your morning blend
item.description: A 50% U.S. tariff on Brazilian coffee just kicked in — and it's shaking up global supply chains. As American roasters scramble for alternatives, Colombia is cashing in. But how long will the beans — and prices — hold?

item.title: NPR founding mother Susan Stamberg reflects on her career and favorite memories
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with correspondent and former All Things Considered and Weekend Edition host, Susan Stamberg, about her career as she retires from the network this week.

item.title: Young GOP candidates are handling their congressional bids differently from Democrats
item.description: A growing number of young Democrats have stepped up to run for Congress calling for generational change. Young Republicans seem to be following a different playbook, holding off on bids of their own.

item.title: In a major antitrust ruling, a judge lets Google keep Chrome but levies other penalties
item.description: A federal judge ruled against breaking up Google, but is barring it from making exclusive deals to make its search engine the default on phones and other devices.

item.title: Court records show a nuanced picture of just how much Trump is tackling D.C. crime
item.description: It's been several weeks since President Trump federalized the Washington, D.C., police force. NPR breaks down the data on who's been arrested and what they're charged with in the city.

item.title: Scientists react to the news that their genes put them at high risk for Alzheimer's
item.description: People who inherit two copies of a common gene variant are very likely to develop Alzheimer's disease. Learning you are one of those people can be tough. Three scientists are in this situation.

item.title: Broadcasting pioneer Jayne Kennedy opens up on triumphs and heartbreaks in new memoir
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks to barrier-breaking sports broadcaster Jayne Kennedy about her new memoir.

item.title: How three businesses are coping with tariff limbo
item.description: US importers are in a kind of tariff limbo. A federal appeals court has struck down most of President Trump's import taxes. But the tariffs are still being collected, for now, until there's a final decision from the Supreme Court.
